TEXT.citation: Early, R. J., & Whitehorn, J. (2003). One hundred Paiwan texts. Pacific Linguistics, Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, The Australian National University.
TEXT.BibTeX_citation: @book{100paiwantexts, author = {Robert Early and John Whitehorn}, title = {One Hundred Paiwan Texts}, year = {2003}, publisher = {Pacific Linguistics, Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, The Australian National University}}
TEXT.source: told by Giłgiław of Vałulu village

S.FORM: nu seman puvasan dangdangan anan, sana łama-i, sana qusuli.
no seman povasan dangdangan anan, sana ljama-i, sana qosoli.
S.TRANSL: TARO: When we make a taro field, we clear the ground and burn the vegetation and dig out the roots.

S.FORM: nu qinusul anga, nu sariqsiqsiq a kadjunangan, qułitsan anga sakamaya.
no qinosol anga, no sariqsiqsiq a kadjonangan, qoljican anga sakamaya.
S.TRANSL: When we have dug out the roots, if the soil is dry we just clear away the burnt vegetation.

S.FORM: łakua nu djukel a kadjunangan.
ljakoa no djokel a kadjonangan.
S.TRANSL: But if the soil is sticky

S.FORM: tjara djukulen anan a semualap a qipu izua i ta tjapungułan, sana qułiqułitsi sa łama-i a qinepuan, sana taletalemi tua vasa.
tjara djokolen anan a semoalap a qipo izoa i ta tjapongoljan, sana qoljiqoljici sa ljama-i a qinepoan, sana taletalemi toa vasa.
S.TRANSL: we always beat the soil out of the roots, and then clear up and burn the refuse; and then plant the taro.

S.FORM: a siqusulan siumał a upu a pasekaumał.
a siqosolan siomalj a opo a pasekaomalj.
S.TRANSL: When we are digging out the roots we renew the terrace walls in new positions.

S.FORM: nu seman puvaquan namaya tua puvasan a dangdangan anan sana łama-i sana kavatsuki.
no seman povaqoan namaya toa povasan a dangdangan anan sana ljama-i sana kavacoki.
S.TRANSL: MILLET: When we make a millet field, it’s the same as a taro field; we cut back and burn the vegetation and clear the land.

S.FORM: qau nu mavatsuk itjen, mumał tua upu a zuma nu qałan; łakua tjatjuruvu a inika mumaumał tua upu nu mavatsuk.
qao no mavacok itjen, momalj toa opo a zoma no qaljan; ljakoa tjatjorovo a inika momaomalj toa opo no mavacok.
S.TRANSL: When we have cleared the land, in some villages they renew the terrace walls; but there are more people who don’t renew the walls after clearing the land.

S.FORM: aitsu a puvaquan inika namaya tua puvasan a djukulen.
aico a povaqoan inika namaya toa povasan a djokolen.
S.TRANSL: In millet fields we don’t beat the soil as in taro fields.

S.FORM: qułitsan anga sakamaya sa tjuguti.
qoljican anga sakamaya sa tjogoti.
S.TRANSL: We just clear away the vegetation and sow the millet.

S.FORM: aitsu a pusutjavan mamaw katua puvasan a siqusulan a mumał tua upu aitsu a pusutjavan.
aico a posotjavan mamaw katoa povasan a siqosolan a momalj toa opo aico a posotjavan.
S.TRANSL: PEANUTS Peanut fields are like taro fields; the terrace walls are renewed when the roots are dug out.

S.FORM: a puvasan maretimałimałi a sitaleman.
a povasan maretimaljimalji a sitaleman.
S.TRANSL: There are different times for planting taro fields,

S.FORM: mapalalailaing a kinaqałaqałan.
mapalalailaing a kinaqaljaqaljan.
S.TRANSL: depending on the village.

S.FORM: a zuma nu qałan temalem nu 1, 2 gatsu.
a zoma no qaljan temalem no 1, 2 gaco.
S.TRANSL: Some villages plant in January or February;

S.FORM: a zuma nu qałan temalem anga nu 3, 4, 5 gatsu.
a zoma no qaljan temalem anga no 3, 4, 5 gaco.
S.TRANSL: others in March to May.

S.FORM: aitsu a sitaleman kemasi tua pinutsaviłan a patje 5 gatsu.
aico a sitaleman kemasi toa pinocaviljan a patje 5 gaco.
S.TRANSL: Planting goes on from New Year to May.

S.FORM: aitsu a puvasan pataudan tua puk tua djulis.
aico a povasan pataodan toa pok toa djolis.
S.TRANSL: We also plant tree-beans and goose-foot in taro fields.

S.FORM: nu nanguaq a kadjunangan, pataudan tua łapanay tua qarizang a temalem.
no nangoaq a kadjonangan, pataodan toa ljapanay toa qarizang a temalem.
S.TRANSL: If the soil is good we also plant maize or green-beans.

S.FORM: nu 11, 12, 1 gatsu kivasa.
no 11, 12, 1 gaco kivasa.
S.TRANSL: We harvest taro in November to January.

S.FORM: a puvaquan nu 2, 3 gatsu, nu mavilił 4 gatsu, nu matalu 1 gatsu a sitjugutan.
a povaqoan no 2, 3 gaco, no mavililj 4 gaco, no matalo 1 gaco a sitjogotan.
S.TRANSL: Millet fields are planted in February or March, or April for late planting, or January for early planting.

S.FORM: qau pataudan tua łumay tua puk tua qarizang tua djulis tua łangga tua łapanay.
qao pataodan toa ljomay toa pok toa qarizang toa djolis toa ljangga toa ljapanay.
S.TRANSL: We mix in barnyard millet, tree-beans, green-beans, goose-foot, sesame(?) or maize.

S.FORM: nu 7, 8 gatsu kivaqu.
no 7, 8 gaco kivaqo.
S.TRANSL: We harvest millet in July or August.

S.FORM: a pusutjavan 3, 4 gatsu a sitaletaleman i vurasian, sa talemi tua łapanay qarizang tua puk łangga.
a posotjavan 3, 4 gaco a sitaletaleman i vorasian, sa talemi toa ljapanay qarizang toa pok ljangga.
S.TRANSL: A peanut field is planted in March or April in a sweet-potato field, and is planted with maize, green-beans, tree-beans or sesame.

S.FORM: nu 8, 9 gatsu kisutjaven.
no 8, 9 gaco kisotjaven.
S.TRANSL: We harvest peanuts in August or September.

S.FORM: a puvurasian a pusavidan inika patautaudan a
a povorasian a posavidan inika pataotaodan a
S.TRANSL: temalem.
